ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms

From: Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] New Paper: Ontogeny tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=467342474; y=x7L7VJNKscOlwOKjw6GRGwZuwYKnEwQwSE_bPqI56wd67HS-80aQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello Ken,

I agree with mostly everything you said. If we disagree about a=
nything, I think it is a semantic issue of when to start using an adjective=
 within a certain dimension. 

See below for details. 

> Hi Jeff, congrats=
 on another very interesting and thought-provoking paper. 

Thanks. 

> I a=
gree with some of your points from your post but I also wanted to mention a=
 couple where I differ. 
> 
> I agree strongly with your conclusion that si=
mply because phenotypic diversity is a good thing does not mean that genoty=
pic diversity should be discarded. They play different and complementary ro=
les. I'm glad to hear you drew that conclusion from this work.
> 
> Where I=
 somewhat differ is on the "bolting on" issue. You mentioned that I have po=
inted out that in target-based search evolution "never takes the time to re=
design from the ground up" and keeps "hacking in/bolting on new things that=
 happen to work." However, I would like to make a distinction between your =
characterization and my view. First, my view is that *all* evolution "never=
 takes the time to redesign from the ground up" and keeps "hacking in/bolti=
ng on new things that happen to work," both in non-objective and objective-=
based evolution. Those are ubiquitous qualities of evolution regardless of =
how it's rewarded: Its mutations are inherently ad hoc and it is virtually =
impossible to "redesign" an ad hoc construction in the middle of a search. =
That's true in nature, in Picbreeder, in objective-based algorithms, and pr=
obably true in Avida (though I'm not experienced in Avida).
> 
> Second, in=
 my view the key distinction between non-objective and objective search is =
that objective search tends to produce representations that are *piecewise*=
. In other words, while both non-object and objective search proceed in an =
ad-hoc "bolting on" manner, the bolted-on components in the objective searc=
h tend to be irregular additions that slightly raise fitness at the expense=
 of ruining the representation for future generations. 

This makes me thin=
k we do disagree a bit about what happens in natural evolution, and simply =
disagree about what to call 'bolting on'. I think in nature (and certainly =
in Avida) we see exactly these same sort of piecewise, irregular additions =
that slightly raise fitness at the expense of ruining the representation fo=
r future generations: that is actually what I mean by 'bolting on.' Where I=
 think we agree is that the problem is worse for target-based search than m=
ore open-ended, diversity encouraging search (e.g natural evolution). It so=
unds like we disagree slightly on how bad the bolting on is in nature. 

> =
That is because in objective search there is no reward for establishing any=
 regularities. In non-objective search, on the other hand, often a regulari=
ty is preserved because it offers something fundamentally new (i.e. neither=
 good nor bad) and then later becomes the basis for endless elaboration (li=
ke bilateral symmetry).
>  You can't establish something like symmetry earl=
y in an objective search because symmetry on its own looks nothing like the=
 final objective, even if theoretically it would be helpful in principle in=
 finding it. 
> 

My instincts tell me that even in natural evolution, most=
 major changes (e.g. bilateral symmetry) are initially bad, and thus select=
ed against. For me, it still is an interesting puzzle how such major change=
s were not immediately selected against in nature. You're right that such m=
ajor changes may be neutral or positive in novelty search. It sounds like w=
e may differ in how much we think nature has objectives. Even if it has no =
overall objective, there is always a pressure to be fit, which prevents a r=
eward for pure exploration and massive changes.   

> I'm also not sure whe=
ther it's really accurate to say Avida is "not target-based." It's true tha=
t it's not as explicit as a single simple objective function, but the fact =
that there are several logical operations that explicitly give an advantage=
 to organisms that execute them actually does create a form of objective-dr=
iven pressure. In other words, the creativity of evolution in Avida with su=
ch a priori human-defined rewards is to some extent hampered by the need to=
 stay competitive on those arbitrary objectives. So I'd expect it to be clo=
ser to objective search (when used in that mode) than non-objective search,=
 though somewhere on the continuum between them. I also understand that Avi=
da as a platform doesn't have to be run with those rewards, but if I unders=
tand correctly they are traditional and used in this particular paper as we=
ll.
> 

I agree with you. Avida is likely more towards non-objective search=
 than target-based search, but probably not by that much. You'd likely get =
a stronger argument from Charles Ofria about it being more open-ended, but =
I've always thought that Avida (and all alife simulations) are still rather=
 target-based. That's why I don't put too much stock in the argument that n=
ot having an explicit fitness function makes some alife simulations more in=
teresting: I usually think they do have an explicit fitness function, it's =
just a complicated one that we don't understand as much as others. 

> Howe=
ver, I think these differences in perspective don't really detract from the=
 main point of the paper regarding ontogeny and phylogeny. But I mention th=
em mainly as a side-conversation on objective vs. non-objective search and =
their effects.
> 

I agree. None of these issues relate to the major contri=
bution of the paper. These subjects are more the sort of things I thought a=
bout as implications for my paper for the subjects discussed on this list. =
I'm glad to have the chance to discuss them here. 

Thanks for letting me k=
now your thoughts,
Jeff

> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune=
 <jeffclune@...> wrote:
> >
> > Hello all,
> > 
> > I wanted to let you kno=
w about a new paper I recently published. I did not use NEAT, but there are=
 messages in the paper that relate to some of the conversations we've had o=
n this list.
> > 
> > Clune J, Pennock RT, Ofria C, Lenski RE
> > Ontogeny =
tends to recapitulate phylogeny in digital organisms. 
> > The American Nat=
uralist. 2012. 180: E54=96E63.
> > PDF: http://jeffclune.com/publications/2=
012-CluneEtAl-OntegenyRecapitulatesPhylogeny-AmNat.pdf
> > Popular press wr=
iteup of the paper: http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/08/1208101331=
55.htm
> > 
> > The first relevant subject regards evolving good representa=
tions. The work of Joel, Ken, and colleagues has shown some interesting thi=
ngs regarding when we can expect bad representations, such as in target-bas=
ed search, where evolution keeps hacking in/bolting on new things that happ=
en to work, and never takes the time to redesign from the ground up (or eve=
n at middle levels). Nature, however, does something similar (though perhap=
s to a much lesser degree): vestigial organs and developmental stages hang =
around, including intermediate developmental forms that are built and then =
dissolve entirely. In this paper we looked into whether we could see eviden=
ce of that "bolting on" in Avida, a digital evolution platform that is not =
target-based in that it does not have an explicit fitness function. We foun=
d evidence for bolting on, just as we would expect from the existence of ve=
stigial developmental stages in biological organisms: new functionality ten=
ded to appear later in the development of an organism, because mutations th=
at changed things more fundamentally/deeper in the representation were more=
 likely to be deleterious and were more quickly weeded out by selection. I =
think the lesson is that this bolting on process is largely inevitable, tho=
ugh I think it is a fascinating question whether it is less of an issue in =
divergent search vs. convergent search. 
> > 
> > A second issue related to=
 this list is that, because evolution tends to quickly select away mutation=
s that deeply change representations, it is likely a good idea to have some=
thing like the genomic diversity protection in NEAT. Because recent work ha=
s shown that phenotypic/behavioral diversity is more effective than genotyp=
ic diversity, many people may be switching to phenotypic diversity and aban=
doning genomic diversity: this work suggests that both may be important. Fo=
r example, mutations that affect a representation deeply may initially hurt=
 the organism's ability to do something behaviorally different/interesting,=
 for the same reason that such mutations hurts fitness (e.g. they cripple t=
he organism). Protecting that innovation for a while may thus pay off. In o=
ther words, because selection will quickly work to eliminate deep changes, =
we should probably protect them for a while if we want to see better repres=
entations emerge. 
> > 
> > In the paper, we focus on an interesting conseq=
uence of bolting on: if new functionality is added to the end of an organis=
m's life, then the order that an organism develops will tend to contain inf=
ormation about the order that traits evolved in its lineage, and vice-versa=
. That helps settle an age old debate by showing that "ontogeny tends to re=
capitulate phylogeny". 
> > 
> > Please let me know if you have any questio=
ns or comments. 
> > 
> > Best regards,
> > Jeff Clune
> > 
> > Visiting Sc=
ientist
> > Cornell University
> > jeffclune@...
> > jeffclune.com
> >
> 
>=
